folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Gramercy Park South, at Irving Place (photographer's vantage point), looking northwestward across Gramercy Park, and showing buildings encircling same upon their respective thoroughfares known as Gramercy Fark North (right) and Gramercy Park West (left). Under completion is the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Building at the S.E. corner of Madison AVenue and East 24th Street. Note Calvary Church (P.E.) nestling beneath same. This edifice occupies a site at the N.E. corner of Fourth Avenue and E. 21st Street.
About 1905.
Brown Brothers.

title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place

folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
20 to 23 Gramercy Park South (left), at, adjoining and east of the S.E. corner of Irving Place. No. 20, the corner house, is the former residence of Hamilton Fish, one time U.S. Secretary of State, and No. 21, that of John Bigelow, former U.S. Minister to France and joint editor with Bryant of the New York Post. Also shown (right) is Irving Place, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Gramercy Park South, showing a 3-story stable of the Fish mansion and contiguous to it Nos. 84 and 82. The Fish House, does not bear Irving Place numbers even
though its entrance is upon same.
March 1909.
Brown Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place

folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
16 and 14-15 Gramercy Park South (left to right), south side, west of Irving Place. No. 14-15 is the National Arts Club building; formerly the home of Samuel J. Tilden, one of the founders of the New York Public Library. No. 16 is the home of the Players Club; former residence of Valentine G. Hall and later of Edwin Booth who founded the Club and
presented them the house as a gift.
June 1925.
Neg #1018A
Slide #75
title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place

folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
19 to 25 Gramercy Park South, at, adjoining and east of the S.E. corner of Irving Place, and showing the southeastern portion of Gramercy Park. At the extreme right appears, in part, the Parkside, at the S.A. corner of Irving Place. No. 19-2O is known as the Stuyvesant Chambers; and No. 21 was the residence of John Bigelow, once U.S. Minister to France and joint editor with Bryant, of the New York Evening Post.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place

Gramercy ParkSouth, at Irving Place, showing the Parkside, a 17story residential hotel at the S.W. corner and bearing No. 18. Also shown is a portion of Gramercy Park. The park is for the exclusive
use of residents of the Gramercy Park development.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

The same, another view.

folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Gramercy Park South (extreme foreground), north side, at the head of Irving Place, showing the main gate to Gramercy Park, and across a view northward of Lexington Ave., from Gramercy Jark North, (where it begins). The statue appearing in the center of the Park is that of Edwin Booth in the role of 'rince Hamlet, which was sculptured by Edmond T. Quinn. Shown in the background is the Chrysler Building (right) and Chanin
Building on upper Lexington Ave., at East 42nd Street.
July 11, 1932.
New York Edison Company.

title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place

folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Gramercy Park South, north side, (extreme foreground), at the head of Irving Place, showing the main gate entrance to Gramercy Park and across it a view nonthward of Lexington Ave., from its point of commencement at Gramercy Park North. In the center of the Park is seen a statue of Edwin Booth, greatest Shakesperean actor, in the role of Frince Hamlet, which was sculptured by Edmond T. Quinn. In the background (right to left) are shown the Chrwsler and Chanin Buildings on opposing corners at East 42nd Street. From right to left, across the Park, appear Nos. 45 Gramercy Park North; No. 1 Lexington Ave. (N.E. corner) and No. 52 Gramercy
Park North (N.W. corner).
July 11, 1932.
New York Edison Company.
title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place

folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Gramercy Park South (extreme foreground) north side, at the head of Irving Place, showing the main gate entrance to Gramercy Park and a view northward of Lexington Ave. from its commencement point at Gramercy Park North. The 16-story building, on the left is the Hotel Gramercy Park at the N.W. corner of Gramercy Park North and Lexington Ave. and bearing Nos. 52 and 2, respectively on the above mentioned two streets. On the right is the 12-story building No. 1 Lexington Ave. Also shown in the center of the Park is a statue of Edwin Booth in the role of Hamlet. It was sculptured by Edmond T. Quinn in commemoration of the great Shakesperean actor who lived in this area.
About 1932.
Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place

folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Gramercy Park South, south side, west from Irving Place to Fourth Avenue where this thoroughfare resumes its identity as E. 2Oth Street. The vacant 1ot (No. 17) at the left was formerly the site of the former residence of Ambassador Gerard and will be improved by a low duplex apartment house according to the New York Times of February 25, 1938. West of same are the Players and the National Arts Clubs. The office structure seen at the right is at the S.W. corner of Fourth Avenue and E. 20th Street.
June 1U, 1938.
P.L. Sperr
Side ~22
title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
